G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u0000\u000028.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody order may be modified “upon a showing that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.” G.L. c. 208, §��28; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u0000\u000020\u0000.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, and respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody judgment entered on May 15, 2021, in the above-captioned matter, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §��28, and G.L. c. 209C, §��20�(b), on the grounds that there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the minor children.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody order may be modified “upon a showing that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.” G.L. c. 208, §��28; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on the paternity statute (G.L. c. 209C) and relocation/ removal issues, not modification of a prior custody order under G.L. c. 208, § 28. It does not articulate the “material and substantial change in circumstances” plus “best interests of the child” standard, nor does it interpret § 28. Thus, at least in this excerpt, the case does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is “free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].” Id. at 549-550. As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights. See G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), (b).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court’s paramount concern in all custody matters is the **best interests of the child**, to be determined in light of all relevant circumstances. Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the governing standard in custody cases and reaffirms that the ‘best interests of the child’ is the controlling and paramount consideration, to be applied based on all relevant circumstances. The court traces the historical development of the best-interests standard, cites prior Massachusetts cases describing it as the paramount concern, and applies it in evaluating the custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). This directly supports the proposition for which the case is cited.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt…; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children… (‘the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Court’s paramount concern in all custody matters is the **best interests of the child**, to be determined in light of all relevant circumstances. Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015).
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the custody and visitation analysis around the child’s best interests and explicitly describes that welfare as the paramount concern, consistent with the cited proposition. The court quotes and applies Massachusetts authorities and statutes requiring that custody and visitation determinations focus on the best interests of the child in light of all relevant circumstances, and then evaluates the facts under that standard. Thus, Schechter directly supports the stated principle.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child. … ‘[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ … In exercising discretion, the judge is authorized ‘to consider the widest range of permissible evidence.’ … In this case, the judge made findings…[and] the decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Where evidence indicates that a parent’s household presents a risk of harm, courts have found modification and restrictions on visitation to be warranted. Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with domestic violence and its effect on custody determinations, but it does not hold that evidence of a risky parental household led to modification or restrictions on visitation. Instead, the Supreme Judicial Court reverses and remands for additional findings about the impact of domestic violence and the propriety of joint/primary custody; it neither orders modified or restricted visitation nor articulates a rule that such evidence warrants those measures. Thus, it is related to but does not clearly stand as authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ ... The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. ... Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings."

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Where evidence indicates that a parent’s household presents a risk of harm, courts have found modification and restrictions on visitation to be warranted. Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: This opinion does not discuss a parent’s household presenting a risk of harm or danger to the child, nor does it affirm modification or restrictions on visitation based on such risk. Instead, the Appeals Court reverses a change in custody and permits relocation, emphasizing the absence of any material and substantial change in circumstances and expressly noting that both parents’ homes are safe and appropriate. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition that risk of harm in a parent’s household warrants modification or restricted visitation.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements… To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker. The probate judge took note of the fact that both parents love the child, and that ‘both parents have safe and secure homes. . . . The child is happy in each party’s home.’”

Care & Protection of Walt, 478 Mass. 212.proposition: Massachusetts law prioritizes child safety above all other factors, including parental preferences. Care & Protection of Walt, 478 Mass. 212 (2017); Care & Protection of Vick, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 704 (2016).

Care & Protection of Vick, 89 Mass. App..raw_text: Care & Protection of Vick, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 704 (2016)
Care & Protection of Vick, 89 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts law prioritizes child safety above all other factors, including parental preferences. Care & Protection of Walt, 478 Mass. 212 (2017); Care & Protection of Vick, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 704 (2016).
Care & Protection of Vick, 89 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion emphasizes that the core determination is the child’s welfare and best interests, and it upholds intervention and removal based on risk of harm despite the child’s stated preference to live with his mother. The court explicitly notes that the child’s wishes are not decisive and that the State may act preventively to protect a child from harm. While the case does not use the exact phrasing that safety is “above all other factors,” its reasoning reflects that child safety and protection from harm override contrary parental and child preferences.
Care & Protection of Vick, 89 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “Under these circumstances, where the child has been remarkably resilient despite his neglect by the mother, the judge did not ‘need to wait for inevitable disaster to happen’ before acting in the child’s best interests… ‘the State’s interest in protecting children from suffering harm at the hands of their parents may properly be preventive as well as remedial’… The child’s wishes, however, are neither decisive nor outcome dispositive, and must be considered against the backdrop of the mother’s unfitness, which has been shown here by clear and convincing evidence.”

Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).proposition: In cases involving alleged violence, emotional harm, or dangerous household members, trial courts are authorized to order **supervised visitation or exclude certain individuals** from contact with the children. Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011); Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795 (1993); Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986).
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a judge’s equitable authority to order (or not order) visitation between a child and a biological parent after termination of parental rights, focusing on best-interest and adoptive-parent autonomy. It does not address supervised visitation in situations involving violence, emotional harm, or dangerous household members, nor does it discuss excluding specific individuals from contact. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about supervised visitation or exclusion of dangerous persons.
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).relevant_excerpt: "We have repeatedly recognized the equitable authority of a judge to order visitation between a child and a parent whose parental rights have been terminated, where such visitation is in the child’s best interest. See Adoption of Rico, 453 Mass. 749, 754 (2009); Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 556-561 (2000); E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824, 827-828, cert. denied, 528 U.S. 1005 (1999) (noting broad equity jurisdiction to order visitation)."

Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795 (1993).proposition: In cases involving alleged violence, emotional harm, or dangerous household members, trial courts are authorized to order **supervised visitation or exclude certain individuals** from contact with the children. Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011); Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795 (1993); Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986).
Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795 (1993).support_reasoning: The opinion recounts that, in response to the sexual-abuse allegations and emotional neglect concerns, the Juvenile Court judge ordered that the children’s visits with their mother be supervised and that the mother’s partner (later husband) Flanders have no contact with the children. Although the Supreme Judicial Court ultimately reversed the permanent custody order for lack of clear and convincing evidence of unfitness, it did not question the court’s authority to impose supervised visitation and no-contact conditions; it treated those measures as within the trial court’s remedial powers in such cases.
Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795 (1993).relevant_excerpt: “After a full hearing, the judge granted temporary custody of Eleanor and Carol to the department, ordered that they be placed in foster care, required that their visits with their mother be supervised, and ordered Flanders to have no contact with either child.”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: In cases involving alleged violence, emotional harm, or dangerous household members, trial courts are authorized to order **supervised visitation or exclude certain individuals** from contact with the children. Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011); Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795 (1993); Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986).
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion involves serious physical and emotional abuse and domestic violence, but the relief ordered was permanent commitment of the children to the Department of Social Services, not supervised visitation or exclusion of specific individuals from contact. The only mention of visitation is a description of prior temporary orders (“liberal visitation” and unsupervised visits) and the problems arising from them; the court does not discuss, approve, or direct supervised visitation or the exclusion of household members as a remedy. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “On May 8, 1981, the older child was returned to the care of his parents, and the younger child was scheduled to return home several weeks later. The older child was removed from his parents’ home again on June 15, 1981… The original temporary order of custody provided for ‘liberal visitation.’ After unsupervised visits in November, 1981, the older child complained of being hit. The father admitted to hitting the child because of the boy’s misbehavior.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u0000\u000031A.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §��31A, a history or pattern of abuse by a parent or by a member of that parent’s household shall create a rebuttable presumption that it is not in the child’s best interests to be placed in the custody of that parent.

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: A related statute, G.L. c. 209A, empowers this Court to take protective measures where abuse is shown or reasonably feared.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u0000\u00006.proposition: Under G.L. c. 215, §��6, the Probate and Family Court has full equity jurisdiction to issue and enforce custody orders protecting minors.
